identificationModule.briefTitle: A New Parameter Derived From DSA to Evaluate Cerebral Perfusion
identificationModule.officialTitle: The Association Between a New Parameter Derived From DSA and Outcomes in Cerebral Ischemia

descriptionModule.briefSummary: This observational study focus on a new parameter of cerebral perfusion derived form digital substraction angiography.
descriptionModule.detailedDescription:
Ischemic cerebrovascular disease is an important cause of death and disability in the world. Digital Subtraction Angiography (DSA) is the golden index for evaluating cerebral blood vessels. We introduced a new parameter derived from DSA to evaluate the perfusion to predict the outcomes in acute stroke with large vessel occlusion.

To study the possible relationship between the new parameter of cerebral perfusion derived from DSA and outcomes in cerebral ischemia（modified Rankin Scale）, we intend to retrospectively analyze the images derived from patients who undergone the DSA and follow-up outcomes（modified Rankin Scale）.

armGroups.label: good perfusion in DSA
armGroups.description: We introduced a new parameter derived from DSA to evaluate the perfusion in cerebral ischemia.(good perfusion)

armGroups.label: middle perfusion in DSA
armGroups.description: We introduced a new parameter derived from DSA to evaluate the perfusion in cerebral ischemia.(middle perfusion)

armGroups.label: poor perfusion in DSA
armGroups.description: We introduced a new parameter derived from DSA to evaluate the perfusion in cerebral ischemia.(poor perfusion)

primaryOutcomes.measure: the outcomes between good perfusions and poor perfusions
primaryOutcomes.description: Results are reported as odds ratios (ORs) with 95% confidence intervals (CIs).

secondaryOutcomes.measure: the outcomes between good perfusions and middle perfusions
secondaryOutcomes.description: Results are reported as odds ratios (ORs) with 95% confidence intervals (CIs).

eligibilityModule.eligibilityCriteria:
Inclusion Criteria:

1. Cerebral ischemia
2. patients undergone DSA

Exclusion Criteria:

1.cerebral hemorrhage
eligibilityModule.studyPopulation: the study population is from primary care clinic
